title.narrative: Providing emergency life-saving WASH assistance to the most vulnerable populations in North West Syria

description.narrative:
Aligned with the Syria HRP 2021 objectives and according to the Humanitarian Needs Assessment Programme (HNAP), the proposed project aims to provide life-saving humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable people affected by the escalation of violence in southern Idleb and western countryside of Aleppo, Most IDPs (in camps, informal settlements and among host community members in villages) continue to face critical WaSH needs, including a lack of water tanks and sustainable solid waste solutions (garbage bins, sewage networks). This is particularly problematic in light of the COVID pandemic. Findings from the CCCM Cluster confirm that, despite the humanitarian presence, WaSH needs are still not fully covered in Azaz. In fact, according to Humanitarian Needs Assessment Programme (HNAP) report of Dec 2020, 40 % of IDPs in NWS report that water is their first priority. In terms of infrastructure, at least 70% of sewage is discharged untreated, while at least half of the sewerage systems are not functional and 26% of garbage is inappropriately disposed within communities (HNO 2020), with 64% of water stations not functional, according to the Syrian Water Resources Platform.
SI addresses identified needs with a comprehensive WASH approach:
Provision of comprehensive WaSH package for IDPs in Mare, Aza, Suran and Akhtarin camps and Informal Settlements Daily supply of safe, sufficient and treated water in the form of water points for an average of 35 Litter per person per day through water trucking and pumping (running cost). Water distribution and quality monitoring will be implemented in the full respect of the WASH cluster technical recommendations Procurement, distribution and installation of water storage containers for water domestic use and hygiene behaviors Solid waste collection and management through provision of adequate solid containers Life-saving hygiene promotion awareness will be ensured within and beyond recently displaced people to prevent water and vector borne diseases. Distribution of 3000 comprehensive Hygiene-COVID kits in alliance with COVID response for 3,000 HHs (15,442 individuals) Water network rehabilitation in Suran village.
Targeting will be based on needs analysis, inter-agency coordination, and SI ability to maintain humanitarian safe and principled access. Beneficiary selection criteria for individual activities will vary, but always be based on needs and vulnerabilities. Gender equality will be prioritized and beneficiary engagement throughout the project cycle will ensure transparency and awareness of project activities.
This project is in accordance with the first Strategic Objective of the interagency Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP): Provide life-saving humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable people with an emphasis on those in areas with high severity of needs. SI will target locations ranked by SCHF as having high and medium needs, in which it will address Allocation Strategic Objective 2 (ASO2).
The project is linked to HRP project: HSYR21-WSH-178724-1
